bibl.title: Military Orders for Guy Charles Moore Godfrey, Herbert J. Slocum, and Alexander N. Stark, September 27, 1900 [selected pages]

div1.p: Special Orders #227 relieves Godfrey of duty. Slocum is temporarily assigned duty as Acting Chief Quartermaster. Stark's leave of absence is extended. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Guy Charles Moore Godfrey, Herbert J. Slocum, and Alexander N. Stark, September 27, 1900 [selected pages]
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2
1900
Godfrey - Slocum - Stark

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 227. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, September 27, 1900.

1. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing-named enlisted men, now at the stations designated after
their respective names, will be discharged from the Army, by
way of favor, by the commanding officers of their respective
stations:

Private Raymond E. Cornwell, Troop M, 7th Cavalry, Co-
lumbia Barracks, Havana, Cuba;

Private Alpha L. Walker, Battery C, 4th Artillery, Fort
Caswell, North Carolina.
These soldiers are not entitled to travel-pay.

2. Private James H. Kennedy, Troop F, 5th Cavalry, San
Juan, Porto Rico, is transferred to Battery G, 5th Artillery,
stationed at that post, and will report to the commanding officer
thereof for duty. The expenses of the transfer, if any, will be
borne by the soldier.

3. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private Paul
Tatoolian, Troop G, 8th Cavalry, Guantanamo, Cuba, will be
discharged from the Army by the commanding officer of his
station, by reason of being unsuited to the service. This sol-
dier is entitled to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Hubert Howell. Company K, 23d Infantry, Fort D. A. Russell,
Wyoming, is transferred to the Hospital Corps. Upon receipt
of this order at the post the commanding officer will order the
soldier to report to the surgeon for duty at the hospital.

5. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Oliver F. Vanaces, Light Battery B, 4th Artillery, Fort Riley,
Kansas, will be discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by
the commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not en-
titled to travel-pay.

6. Private Samuel L. Cohen, Troop L, 2d Cavalry, Matan-
zas, Cuba, is transferred to Troop B, 7th Cavalry. He will be
sent to the station of that troop, Havana, Cuba, and will re-
port upon arrival to the commanding officer for duty. The
expenses of the transfer will be borne by the soldier.

person to the commanding officer of the Army and Navy Gen-
eral Hospital for treatment in that hospital. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

15. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, 1st Lieu-
tenant William R. Smith, 1st U. S. Artillery, will remain on
duty at the U. S. Military Academy, West Point, New York,
until July 1, 1901, when he will proceed to join his battery.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

16. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
Guy C. M. Godfrey, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, is relieved
from the further operation of paragraph 18,Special Orders,
No. 194, August 18, 1900, from this office, and will comply
with paragraph 25, Special Orders, No. 185, August 8, 1900,
from this office.
✓

17. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
William R. Hamilton, 7th U. S. Artillery, is detailed tempo-
rarily as a member of the examining board appointed to meet
at Governors Island, New York City, by Special Orders, No.
72, March 27, 1900, from this office, during the absence of
Major John M. K. Davis, 1st U. S. Artillery, who will resume
his seat on the board upon his return to his proper station.
Such journeys as may be required of Captain Hamilton from
his station to Governors Island and return, in attending the
meetings of the board, are necessary for the public service.

18. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Major
Edward T. Comegys, surgeon, U. S. Army, medical supply
officer at Taku, China, will ship all medical supplies not re-
quired by the troops to remain in China to Manila, Philippine
Islands, and then proceed to Manila and report in person to the
commanding general, Division of the Philippines, for assign-
ment to duty as medical supply officer at that place. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

19. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
William M. Ekin, assistant quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers,
now at Nagasaki, Japan, will proceed to San Francisco, Cali-
fornia, and report by telegraph to the Adjutant General of the
Army for further orders. The travel enjoined is necessary for
the public service.
✓

20. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
Herbert J. Slocum, 7th U. S. Cavalry, will report in person to
5
the commanding general, Department of Western Cuba, for
assignment to duty temporarily as acting chief quartermaster
of that department.

21. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Acting
Assistant Surgeon W. J. S. Stewart, U. S. Army, now on leave
of absence from Fort Slocum, New York, will report to the med-
ical superintendent, Army transport service, Army Building,
New York City, for assignment to temporary duty on the
transport “Rawlins,” during the absence on leave of Acting
Assistant Surgeon William B. Orear, U. S. Army, and upon
the return of that officer will rejoin his proper station.

22. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, leave of
absence from about November 1, 1900, to and including Febru-
ary 4, 1901, is granted Colonel Albert Hartsuff, assistant sur-
geon general, U. S. Army, and he is granted permission to go
beyond sea.

23. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the leave
of absence granted Captain Alexander N. Stark, assistant sur-
geon, U. S. Army, in Special Orders, No. 149, August 30, 1900,
Division of Cuba, is extended seven days.
✓

24. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Acting
Assistant Surgeon Cosam J. Bartlett, U. S. Army, is relieved
from duty in the Department of California, and will proceed
from San Francisco to Port Valdez, Alaska, and report in per-
son to the commanding officer of that post for duty and by
letter to the commanding general, Department of Alaska,
relieving Acting Assistant Surgeon Neil C. Trew, U. S. Army,
who upon being thus relieved will proceed to San Francisco,
California, and report in person to the commanding general,
Department of California, for assignment to duty. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

25. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
Samuel Reber, Signal Corps, U. S. Army, will proceed from
Governors Island, New York, to this city, and will carry out
such instructions as he may receive from the Acting Chief
Signal Officer of the Army, and upon the completion of this
duty will return to his proper station. The travel enjoined is
necessary for the public service.

26. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Major
Cunliffe H. Murray, inspector general, U. S. Volunteers,
